title: Yuliya Veysberg
text:
Yuliya Lazarevna Veysberg (Yuliya Rimskaya-Korsakova) (Julia Weissberg) (b. , d. March 1, 1942) was a <a href="Russians">Russian</a> music critic and composer.
Life and career.
Yuliya Veysberg was born in <a href="Orenburg%2C%20Russia">Orenburg, Russia</a>. She studied at the Women's University, and in 1912 graduated from <a href="St.%20Petersburg%20Conservatory">St. Petersburg Conservatory</a> where she studied composition under <a href="Nikolai%20Rimsky-Korsakov">Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov</a>. From 1912 to 1914 she continued her studies in Berlin with <a href="Engelbert%20Humperdinck%20%28composer%29">Engelbert Humperdinck</a> and <a href="Max%20Reger">Max Reger</a>.
She married <a href="Andrey%20Rimsky-Korsakov">Andrey Rimsky-Korsakov</a>, musicologist and son of <a href="Nikolai%20Rimsky-Korsakov">Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov</a>, and from 1915 to 1917 served on the editorial board of the first Russian music magazine, "Muzïkal'nïy sovremennik", which he founded. She died in <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> during the <a href="Siege%20of%20Leningrad">Siege of Leningrad</a> conducted by <a href="Nazi">Nazi</a> German troops.
Works.
Veysberg's compositions included vocal works, a symphony, a <a href="scherzo">scherzo</a>, and a fantasia. Selected works include:
